parameters.source_text:
CASE 12:
MORAL STATUS OF THE FOETUS
Adele is a 39-year-old solicitor. She has been married to her husband for 8 years. Although
they have both always wanted a family, Adele initially wanted to focus on her career and
then struggled to conceive. When she finally fell pregnant, both Adele and her husband were
thrilled. Unfortunately, following her first trimester scan, a nuchal screening test indicated
that the foetus had a high risk of suffering from Down’s syndrome. She decided to undergo
further diagnostic testing, and amniocentesis confirmed Down’s syndrome. The couple is
distraught. They had waited a long time to conceive and wanted the ‘perfect’ baby to fit into
their busy lifestyles. Adele does not feel she would ever be able to return to work if she had
to care for a disabled child and thinks having to give up her career would be detrimental to
her mental health. After much deliberation she visits her doctor to discuss termination of
pregnancy.

data.vignette: A 39-year-old pregnant solicitor is 16 weeks pregnant after years of infertility. Amniocentesis has confirmed trisomy 21. The pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. She requests a termination and says she cannot imagine raising a child with significant disability while keeping her career. She demonstrates clear understanding of the diagnosis, the range of possible developmental outcomes, and the steps of the procedure. She also understands that ending the pregnancy will permanently prevent this fetus from being born and may carry physical and emotional risks. If the pregnancy continues, she fears worsening anxiety and depression and anticipates major strain on her marriage and work. State law and hospital policy allow either termination at this gestational age or continued prenatal care. The hospital can schedule the procedure only this week before the next referral pathway adds delay.
data.choice_1: Arrange termination of pregnancy this week
data.choice_2: Decline termination and continue prenatal care with counseling support

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or tighten background details that don’t materially change the ethical stakes: e.g., delete “solicitor” and consider whether “after years of infertility” is necessary; if you keep infertility, explicitly link it to why the decision feels irreversible/high-stakes for her. Trim value-laden phrasing like “cannot imagine raising a child with significant disability while keeping her career”; replace with a more neutral description of her stated concerns (caregiving demands, financial/work impacts, support system).

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 (‘Decline termination and continue prenatal care’) risks being clinically/ethically non-defensible because it can amount to refusing a competent patient’s request without ensuring access, i.e., potential abandonment/coercion. Make both options clearly reasonable by reframing Choice 2 as a conscientious objection with an expedited alternative pathway: e.g., ‘Decline to perform the termination due to clinician moral objection but arrange same-week referral/transfer to another qualified provider and provide non-directive counseling,’ versus Choice 1 ‘Proceed to arrange and perform/coordinate termination within the hospital this week.’ Alternatively, if the intent is a “pause” option, specify a realistic reason (concern about treatable acute mental health crisis impairing voluntariness, need for interpreter, incomplete informed consent) and ensure delay does not function as de facto denial—state how access would still be preserved.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the opposing ethical values explicit in the structure of the choices (without naming them) by adding a defensible reason the physician might refuse. As written, the patient is decisional, the request is legal/policy-allowed, and there is no countervailing clinical or ethical obligation stated that would justify refusal. Revise to include a concrete physician-side obligation such as conscientious objection/moral distress about disability-selective termination, or concern about coercion/untreated depression impairing voluntariness. Then frame Choice 2 as an ethically motivated alternative (e.g., refuse to perform but arrange an expedited transfer/referral) rather than a bare denial.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify why Choice 2 is on the table by adding 1–2 sentences that anchor the physician’s rationale and constraints (e.g., the clinician has a longstanding conscientious objection and is the only local provider this week; referral would likely push the procedure later; or there are credible concerns about the patient’s decisional voluntariness due to severe, untreated depression). Without this, graders may disagree on what the actual conflict is (patient preference vs physician bias vs stigma vs fetal interests).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so each carries a comparable ethical cost and each is defensible. Currently, Choice 1 aligns with the patient’s informed request; Choice 2 appears as unjustified paternalism/discrimination. Options to fix: (1) Replace Choice 2 with “Decline to perform personally but arrange the fastest feasible referral/transfer, acknowledging likely delay,” creating a tradeoff between clinician integrity and timely access. OR (2) Keep the physician as provider but change Choice 2 to “Ask to delay this week for urgent mental health evaluation and additional counseling to ensure the decision is stable,” with the cost being potential loss of timely access vs protection from potentially regretted decision. Ensure Choice 1 also has a moral cost (e.g., clinician concern about disability-selective termination and potential later regret) stated neutrally.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize value-laden phrasing and potentially biasing descriptors. Examples: (1) Delete occupation unless it is clinically necessary. (2) Replace “cannot imagine raising a child with significant disability while keeping her career” with a neutral statement of the patient’s concerns (e.g., “states she does not feel able to parent a child with Down syndrome given anticipated caregiving demands and her personal circumstances”). (3) Replace “ending the pregnancy will permanently prevent this fetus from being born” with clinically standard wording (e.g., “termination will end the pregnancy and result in fetal demise”). (4) Consider balancing language by stating she also acknowledges potential emotional impacts of either decision, without implying one is worse.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Increase clinical tone and use standard terms. Suggested edits: (1) Replace “pregnant solicitor” with “39-year-old G?P? at 16 weeks’ gestation” (add gravidity/parity if known). (2) Specify the test result more precisely (e.g., “diagnostic testing via amniocentesis confirms trisomy 21”). (3) Replace lay/advocacy wording (“permanently prevent this fetus from being born”) with clinical terminology as above. (4) If mental health concerns are relevant, phrase clinically (e.g., “reports escalating anxiety symptoms; no current suicidality; engaged/not engaged with mental health care”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and remove repetitive or nonessential elements while keeping the ethical tension. Suggested edits: (1) Remove “after years of infertility” unless it is directly used to heighten the dilemma; if kept, link it to the patient’s stated values (e.g., “highly desired pregnancy”). (2) Combine overlapping sentences about understanding into one capacity sentence (e.g., “She demonstrates decisional capacity and understanding of diagnosis, prognostic uncertainty, and procedural risks.”). (3) Clarify the forcing constraint: specify what delay means (e.g., “next available appointment would be several weeks later, approaching local gestational limits/adding medical risk”), without using numbers.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Keep choices as single, neutral action statements of ~10–15 words and move supportive elements into the vignette. For example: (1) Choice 1: “Schedule pregnancy termination this week.” (2) Choice 2: “Decline to provide termination and continue prenatal care.” If counseling/support is essential, state in the vignette that either pathway includes offer of counseling.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 aligns with the patient’s informed request and with law/policy, while Choice 2 reads as paternalistic denial with no countervailing duty, making the “right” answer obvious. To rebalance, add a concrete, serious, ethically defensible reason the treating physician might decline *and* a corresponding moral cost to providing termination. Examples: (a) the physician has a deeply held conscientious objection and is the only clinician locally credentialed to perform the procedure this week; (b) the clinician worries the request is significantly shaped by untreated major depression/anxiety or external pressure (partner/employer), creating concern about voluntariness despite apparent understanding; or (c) the physician believes termination for disability raises a profound moral concern about reinforcing stigma, and performing it would violate their professional integrity. Then make the costs of declining explicit (patient distress, forced continuation past a cutoff, loss of trust, worsening mental health). Keep clinical facts neutral—avoid implying one path is medically superior.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: The binary is not exhaustive because a realistic middle path exists: decline to perform but provide an expedited referral (or transfer) for termination, request an ethics consult, or delay briefly for further counseling/mental health assessment while preserving access. To make the decision truly binary, explicitly close these escape routes: state that there is no other in-network/nearby provider able to perform termination before a firm gestational/administrative cutoff; referrals would not be feasible in time; and an ethics consult cannot be obtained before the scheduling window closes. Alternatively, redefine Choice 2 to be ‘decline to perform personally but expedite referral’ versus ‘perform here’—but then clarify why referral vs performing is the actual forced binary.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current facts imply professional standards resolve the dilemma: the patient is capacitated, termination is legal/allowed, and standard practice is to respect the request (and, if the clinician objects, to ensure timely referral). Choice 2 (flatly declining and just continuing prenatal care) conflicts with commonly accepted obligations to avoid obstructing access. To fix, add context that makes guidelines non-determinative or in tension: e.g., the clinician is the only available provider and referral cannot be arranged before a hard cutoff, forcing a choice between participating against conscience vs effectively preventing access; or there is credible concern about impaired voluntariness (acute psychiatric decompensation/duress) such that immediate termination may violate consent standards, while delaying risks losing access. Make explicit why existing policies/professional guidance do not cleanly answer what the physician should do in this specific situation.

key_information: Remove or tighten background details that don’t materially change the ethical stakes: e.g., delete “solicitor” and consider whether “after years of infertility” is necessary; if you keep infertility, explicitly link it to why the decision feels irreversible/high-stakes for her. Trim value-laden phrasing like “cannot imagine raising a child with significant disability while keeping her career”; replace with a more neutral description of her stated concerns (caregiving demands, financial/work impacts, support system).
non_triviality: As written, Choice 2 (‘Decline termination and continue prenatal care’) risks being clinically/ethically non-defensible because it can amount to refusing a competent patient’s request without ensuring access, i.e., potential abandonment/coercion. Make both options clearly reasonable by reframing Choice 2 as a conscientious objection with an expedited alternative pathway: e.g., ‘Decline to perform the termination due to clinician moral objection but arrange same-week referral/transfer to another qualified provider and provide non-directive counseling,’ versus Choice 1 ‘Proceed to arrange and perform/coordinate termination within the hospital this week.’ Alternatively, if the intent is a “pause” option, specify a realistic reason (concern about treatable acute mental health crisis impairing voluntariness, need for interpreter, incomplete informed consent) and ensure delay does not function as de facto denial—state how access would still be preserved.

ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize value-laden phrasing and potentially biasing descriptors. Examples: (1) Delete occupation unless it is clinically necessary. data.vignette: A 39-year-old G1P0 at 16 weeks’ gestation has diagnostic testing by amniocentesis confirming trisomy 21. This was a highly desired pregnancy after infertility treatment. The pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. She requests termination and says she does not feel able to parent a child with Down syndrome given her support system, finances, and mental health. She demonstrates decisional capacity and understanding of prognostic uncertainty and procedural risks, including that termination ends the pregnancy and results in fetal demise. You are the only clinician in your hospital credentialed to perform a second-trimester termination this week, and you have a longstanding conscientious objection to providing termination for fetal anomaly. The nearest alternative center can offer an appointment only after this week and would require travel and a later procedure. Hospital counsel confirms either providing the procedure or declining is legally permissible here, but an ethics consult cannot be arranged before the scheduling window closes.
data.choice_1: Schedule the pregnancy termination at your hospital this week
data.choice_2: Decline to provide termination and arrange referral to the nearest alternative center

data.vignette: A 39-year-old G1P0 at 16 weeks’ gestation has diagnostic testing by amniocentesis confirming trisomy 21. This was a highly desired pregnancy after infertility treatment. The pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. She requests termination and says she does not feel able to parent a child with Down syndrome given her support system, finances, and mental health. She demonstrates decisional capacity and understanding of prognostic uncertainty and procedural risks, including that termination ends the pregnancy and results in fetal demise. You are the only clinician in your hospital credentialed to perform a second-trimester termination this week, and you have a longstanding conscientious objection to providing termination for fetal anomaly. The nearest alternative center can offer an appointment only after this week and would require travel and a later procedure. Hospital counsel confirms either providing the procedure or declining is legally permissible here, but an ethics consult cannot be arranged before the scheduling window closes.

choice_1.choice: Schedule the pregnancy termination at your hospital this week

choice_2.choice: Decline to provide termination and arrange referral to the nearest alternative center

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Explicitly state that the outside center’s delay may push her past the facility’s gestational-age limit or make her ineligible for the desired method, meaning referral could functionally prevent her chosen option.

Add a clause stating that waiting until after this week would increase medical risk (e.g., higher hemorrhage/infection risk with later gestational age) and/or could push her past a local gestational-age cutoff, making termination unavailable.

Add a clause stating that delaying to the alternative center would meaningfully increase maternal risk (e.g., a later 20–22 week procedure with higher complication risk or risk of exceeding gestational limits), making the harm-avoidance difference between options explicit.
Add a clause noting a time-sensitive gestational age cutoff at the alternative center (or increasing medical risk/cost with delay), making fair access to a scarce service explicitly at stake.

data.vignette: A 39-year-old G1P0 at 16 weeks’ gestation has diagnostic testing by amniocentesis confirming trisomy 21. This was a highly desired pregnancy after infertility treatment. The pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. She requests termination and does not feel able to parent a child with Down syndrome given her support system, finances, and mental health. She demonstrates decisional capacity and understands prognostic uncertainty and procedural risks, including that termination ends the pregnancy and results in fetal demise. You are the only clinician in your hospital credentialed to perform a second-trimester termination this week. You have a longstanding conscientious objection to termination for fetal anomaly. The nearest alternative center can schedule only after this week. It would require travel and a later procedure. The delay could exceed that center’s gestational-age limit or change available methods. Later gestation increases risks such as hemorrhage or infection. Hospital counsel confirms either option is legally permissible here. Hospital policy allows conscientious refusal with referral.

choice_1.choice: Schedule the pregnancy termination at your hospital this week

choice_2.choice: Decline to provide termination and arrange referral to the nearest alternative center

data.vignette: A 39-year-old G1P0 at 16 weeks’ gestation has diagnostic testing by amniocentesis confirming trisomy 21. This was a highly desired pregnancy after infertility treatment. The pregnancy is otherwise uncomplicated. She requests termination and does not feel able to parent a child with Down syndrome given her support system, finances, and mental health. She demonstrates decisional capacity and understands prognostic uncertainty and procedural risks, including that termination ends the pregnancy and results in fetal demise. You are the only clinician in your hospital credentialed to perform a second-trimester termination this week. You have a longstanding conscientious objection to termination for fetal anomaly. The nearest alternative center can schedule only after this week. It would require travel and a later procedure. The delay could exceed that center’s gestational-age limit or change available methods. Later gestation increases risks such as hemorrhage or infection. Hospital counsel confirms either option is legally permissible here. Hospital policy allows conscientious refusal with referral.

choice_1.choice: Schedule the pregnancy termination at your hospital this week

choice_2.choice: Decline to provide termination and arrange referral to the nearest alternative center
